questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose. The lesion has gradually increased in size since it first appeared 11 months ago. He is a farmer and lives together with his wife. His mother died of metastatic melanoma at the age of 67 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 1–2 glasses of whiskey on weekends. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows a nontender lesion at the right medial canthus. An image of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amelanotic melanoma typically manifests as a nonpigmented or hypopigmented nodule or macule. About 5% of nodular melanomas appear amelanotic, and occasionally they may even be associated with ulceration and bleeding, making it difficult to distinguish them from this patient's condition. However, a pearly raised border suggests a much more common type of skin tumor.
Image Description:

A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum manifests as an individual or, more commonly, multiple pearly papules with a central depression. Although it is mostly seen in children, it may also affect adults, especially if they are immunocompromised. However, molluscum contagiosum presents as smaller, nonulcerated lesions (< 5 mm) without telangiectatic pearls or a rolled border.
Image Description:

Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

C) INCORRECT:

While keratoacanthomas may appear as an erythematous nodule with a central crater, which would be consistent with this patient's lesion, they do not have a pearly appearance or a rolled border. In contrast to this patient's lesion, keratoacanthomas typically grow rapidly over 2–3 months and usually heal without treatment.
Image Description:

An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.

These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

D) INCORRECT:

As with this patient's lesion, trichoepithelioma is frequently located on the face, especially on the nose or cheeks. However, it is an uncommon type of skin tumor that is mostly seen in younger patients during puberty or adolescence. It has a firm, skin-colored, papular appearance. A central depression with ulcerations is not a feature of trichoepithelioma.
Image Description:

A solitary, pink nodule on the nasolabial fold with surface vascular markings and central crusting is visible.

E) CORRECT:

This farmer presents with a slow-growing, nontender, pearly nodule with a rolled border and central ulceration, which is consistent with basal cell carcinoma (BCC). Although BCC is the most common malignant skin tumor, it rarely metastasizes and generally has an excellent prognosis. However, untreated lesions may cause local destruction and infiltration. This patient should undergo a full-thickness biopsy of the edge of the lesion for histopathological confirmation of BCC. Afterward, the standard treatments are either surgical excision with a safety margin, or – especially for lesions that involve the face – Mohs micrographic surgery, i.e., layer by layer removal of the carcinoma in which each layer is examined for tumor cells, ensuring complete removal and sparing the uninvolved skin.
Image Description:

A solitary lesion with an irregular, raised, pearly pink border and a multinodular surface with telangiectasia is visible. The center of the lesion appears atrophic and the uppermost nodule shows central ulceration.

F) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is the second most common type of skin cancer and is commonly located on the face or neck (the lower lip is a typical location). Sun exposure and smoking, both present in this patient, are risk factors for cSCC. Although this patient also has a lesion involving his face, SCC has a different appearance: it is typically a hyperkeratotic nodule or ulcer with crusting that does not heal and bleeds easily. A pearly induration with a rolled border suggests another diagnosis.
Image Description:

A solitary, partially pigmented nodule is visible on this patient's lower lip.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

G) INCORRECT:

While actinic keratosis typically affects patients over the age of 50 and is also associated with sun exposure, it does not manifest as pearly nodules surrounding a central, ulcerative depression. Instead, actinic keratosis presents with dry and scaly patches of skin.
Image Description:

Left temporal and cheek region of a 75-year-old female patient with long-term exposure to UV radiation: All three skin lesions are erythematous. There is an atropic crater in the upper lesion. Yellow-brown, squamous changes can be seen in the lower two lesions. This dermatological findings, in association with the patient's history of long-term UV radiation exposure, most likely indicates actinic keratosis.
questions.hint: A slow-growing lesion in a patient with an outdoor occupation and increased sun exposure is in keeping with a certain diagnosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a lesion on his eyelid for 6 months. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. He initially dismissed it as a “skin tag” but the lesion has increased in size over the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and left hemiplegia from a stroke 3 years ago. Current medications include sitagliptin, metformin, aspirin, and simvastatin. He retired 3 years ago from his job as a construction contractor. Examination shows a 1-cm (0.4-in) flesh-colored, nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders. There is no lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is reduced in the left upper and lower extremities. Visual acuity is 20/20. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. A shave biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wide local excision is a surgical procedure in which the tumor and a small margin of normal tissue are removed after the diagnosis has been established. This technique is mainly used for the treatment of melanoma. Although this procedure may also be used to treat BCCs located on the trunk or extremities, the location of this patient's BCC requires a different technique that minimizes the removal of normal tissue.

Wide local excision should not be confused with an excisional biopsy, which is a diagnostic procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cryotherapy can be used for the treatment of superficial BCC, it is not widely accepted as a first-line therapy; recurrence rates are often higher when compared to other therapies. Also, because cryotherapy does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical chemotherapy with imiquimod or 5-fluorouracil is indicated for the treatment of small superficial BCCs. Although topical chemotherapy may be effective in treating some cases of BCC, it is associated with various side effects (redness, edema) and therefore not recommended as a first-line therapy. Additionally, as this technique does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy is an alternative treatment for BCC, usually indicated in the case of large tumors or tumors located in hard to reach locations, or after prior treatment has failed. Because none of these conditions apply, this patient would most likely benefit from a first-line approach.

E) CORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery, a procedure in which the tumor is removed layer by layer and each layer is examined for tumor cells, is the standard treatment for BCCs that are not located on the trunk or extremities. It is especially advantageous for functionally or cosmetically sensitive tumor locations such as the eyelid because it ensures complete tumor removal while sparing unaffected skin. As BCCs do not metastasize, the prognosis is excellent, but close follow-up (every 6–12 months) is warranted to evaluate for local recurrence and new tumors.
Image Description:

Medial canthus of the left eye

An irregularly circumscribed nodule of approximately 0.5 cm in diameter with a central scaling, retraction, and a pearly, cord-like border is seen. In conjunction with the localization, these symptoms suggest basal cell carcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Laser ablation with a carbon dioxide laser is an alternative treatment for superficial BCCs and is often used when other therapies fail. Although this approach may treat some cases of BCC effectively, other techniques are preferred because of lower recurrence rates. Additionally, as this technique does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.
questions.hint: A nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders on the eyelid in an individual with occupational sun exposure suggests basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on her neck for 7 months. It is neither pruritic nor painful. She has tried using over-the-counter topical medications, but none have helped. She has hypertension, hypothyroidism, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, levothyroxine, and pantoprazole. She is a farmer and lives with her two children. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-mm (0.2-in) nontender, indurated, nodular lesion with rolled-out edges on the anterolateral aspect of the neck. There is a central area of ulceration. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to dermoscopy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform a punch biopsy of the center of the lesion
Perform an excisional biopsy of the entire lesion
Perform a wedge biopsy of the lesion and surrounding tissue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of this patient's suspicious lesion facilitates histopathologic confirmation of the diagnosis and provides prognostic information based on the findings. A punch biopsy provides a sample of a portion of the patient's lesion through a relatively simple procedure. However, punch biopsies sample only a limited amount of tissue and might not provide an assessment of tumor histology accurately enough to guide therapy.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's neck lesion has an appearance that is suspicious for BCC and warrants further investigation. A biopsy of this patient's suspicious lesion facilitates histopathologic confirmation of the diagnosis and provides prognostic information based on the findings. A full-thickness biopsy of the lesion allows for the most accurate assessment of the histologic subtype of any tumor found. Excisional biopsy is the preferred type when a neoplasm is suspected.

Clinician preferences guide the selection of biopsy techniques, and a clinician may choose to perform a partial-thickness biopsy because it is easier and less invasive than a full-thickness biopsy. If a residual tumor is suspected, Mohs surgery or another treatment modality may then be used. However, research has shown that partial-thickness biopsies are more likely than full-thickness biopsies to miss important histopathologic features. For lesions that are sufficiently small to be fully removed without excessive cosmetic damage, such as this patient's 5-mm lesion, biopsies should be full-thickness and include normal as well as lesional tissue.
Image Description:

A well-defined nodule with central ulceration, telangiectasia, and pearly-pink rolled-out borders is visible beneath the medial canthus of the left eye.

The location and appearance of this lesion are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical 5-fluorouracil is used to treat superficial BCC and squamous cell carcinoma in situ. However, a diagnosis needs to be established prior to treatment. Furthermore, topical 5-FU has a relatively high rate of adverse effects, is dependent on patient adherence, and has lower clearance rates than other treatment modalities. Therefore, its use is limited to cases in which patients have small tumors in low-risk locations (e.g., the trunk or extremities) and will not or cannot undergo treatment with surgery or other effective therapies.

D) INCORRECT:

Complete surgical excision with appropriate margins can be considered as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for small BCC lesions. However, wide local excision with 1–2-cm margins is only indicated to treat invasive melanoma; surgical margins for BCC should only include 4 mm of surrounding normal-appearing tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is rarely used for the treatment of superficial BCC. It is associated with a relatively high rate of recurrence and poorer cosmetic results (e.g., scarring, hypopigmentation) compared to other treatment options. In addition, a diagnosis of BCC needs to be confirmed in this patient before starting treatment. Cryotherapy is a recommended treatment for actinic keratosis. Though actinic keratosis can manifest as a nontender lesion in sun-exposed skin areas, an indurated, nodular lesion with rolled-out edges on the neck is more suggestive of a diagnosis of BCC. If in doubt, a confirmatory biopsy is indicated to distinguish actinic keratosis from BCCs prior to performing cryotherapy.

F) INCORRECT:

Wedge biopsies are used to evaluate a portion of a large lesion. When the size and location of a lesion facilitate complete removal, another biopsy technique is preferred for suspected neoplasms. For this patient's 5-mm lesion, wedge biopsy would likely result in a poor cosmetic outcome and provide no diagnostic advantage for confirming the diagnosis compared to other modalities.
questions.hint: A slow-growing, nonhealing nodular lesion with rolled-out edges and central ulceration on the neck of an individual with significant sun exposure is suspicious for basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man reports a 7-month history of a slow-growing skin lesion on his left lower eyelid (figure). He has worked as a greenskeeper at a Florida golf course since his 20s. He reports that the lesion is not painful or itchy but bleeds often, particularly when he rubs his eye.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Both squamous-cell carcinoma (SCC) and melanoma can have an appearance similar to that of basal-cell carcinoma but are less common. SCCs typically manifest as erythematous, scaly papules, patches, or plaques caused by abnormal keratinocyte proliferation.
Image Description:

A solitary ulcer, approx. 2 cm in diameter, is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

B) INCORRECT:

Both squamous-cell carcinoma (SCC) and melanoma can have an appearance similar to that of basal-cell carcinoma (BCC) but are less common. Melanomas can have a range of clinical appearances, but the most likely to be mistaken for BCC is an amelanotic melanoma because it presents as a pinkish-red papule. More typical lesions of melanoma are pigmented and asymmetric with irregular borders and color variegation (the “ABCs of melanoma”).
Image Description:

A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyogenic granuloma can also appear similar to basal-cell carcinoma, but the typical presentation is a friable, rapidly developing, vascular-appearing lesion that bleeds readily, not a slow-growing pearly papule. Pyogenic granuloma is much more common in children than adults and usually occurs in the setting of trauma, pregnancy, or the use of certain medications, such as indinavir and isotretinoin.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by multiple small, dome-shaped umbilicated papules. It is caused by a poxvirus and is typically seen in children. It rarely occurs in adults and if it does, it often manifests as a sexually transmitted disease in the genital area or in immunosuppressed patients.
Image Description:

Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

E) CORRECT:

Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC), the most common form of skin cancer in the United States, typically presents as a pearly-pink papule, often with prominent telangiectasias. In patients with dark skin types, the lesion can be skin-colored rather than pinkish-red. In addition, in patients presenting with pigmented BCC, the lesion can appear brown or blue-brown rather than the typical pinkish-red.

Differentiating BCC from squamous-cell carcinoma can sometimes be difficult due to the degree of clinical overlap. Suspicious lesions should therefore be biopsied to determine the diagnosis. If BCC is confirmed, complete removal is indicated, and the patient should be referred to a dermatologist for a complete skin examination and ongoing clinical surveillance, given the risk for additional skin cancers.

Key learning point: The classic presentation of basal-cell carcinoma is a pearly-pink papule, often with prominent telangiectasias.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with a 7-mm asymptomatic lesion on her left upper back (figure). She initially thought she scratched herself on a tree during a hike, but the lesion has persisted for more than a month now.
If the biopsy findings are consistent with the physical examination findings, what is the most appropriate treatment for the lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vismodegib is indicated for metastatic BCC or certain inoperable BCCs.

B) INCORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery uses rapid real-time examination of 100% of the tissue margins via frozen-section specimens. It has a high cure rate, a low recurrence rate, and excellent cosmetic outcomes, but it has a higher cost than an excision. It is recommended for high-risk lesions, including:

• Recurrent lesions
• Lesions >2 cm
• Lesions located on the head or neck (especially the central portion of the face or the eyelids, nose, or ears)
• Lesions with poorly defined borders or high-risk histologic features
• Lesions that have occurred in the setting of immunosuppression

C) INCORRECT:

Intralesional methotrexate is occasionally used for some squamous-cell carcinomas, including certain presentations of keratoacanthomas, but it is not used to treat nodular BCC. Compared with nodular BCCs, squamous-cell carcinomas tend to grow more rapidly, and they typically have a component of scaling or crusting. A pearly, translucent border and telangiectasias are more typical of nodular BCC.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluorouracil cream is used as field therapy to treat numerous actinic keratoses or for superficial BCC (thin, scaly patches), but it is not regularly used to treat nodular BCC. Actinic keratoses typically manifest as scattered pinkish-red macules with adherent, sandpaper-like scale in sun-exposed areas, such as the forehead, helical rim, cheeks, and dorsal surface of the hands.

E) CORRECT:

A small pearly papule with a rolled border, telangiectasias, and central erosion is most consistent with a classic nodular basal-cell carcinoma (BCC). BCC is the most common cancer in the United States. Typical risk factors include blond or red hair, blue or green eyes, light skin color, and ultraviolet light exposure.

If an initial biopsy confirms the suspected diagnosis of BCC in this patient, then excision is the most appropriate treatment, given the nodular nature of the lesion and its location on the trunk. Another option is curettage and electrodesiccation.

Key learning point: Nodular basal-cell carcinomas on the trunk are best treated with excision.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with a friable nodule on her chin (figure) that she first noticed a year ago and initially attributed to trauma from manual epilation of unwanted facial hair. She thinks that the lesion has gotten larger during the past year. She has fair skin and moderate actinic damage.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiosarcomas generally manifest as purplish-red vascular plaques or nodules. They typically occur on the breast following radiation or on the head or neck in older patients. They can also occur on the limbs (such as the Stewart-Treves syndrome after axillary lymph-node dissection).

B) CORRECT:

Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common cancer in the United States and the most common type of skin cancer overall. Lesions are typically pearly, translucent papules or nodules that may become centrally eroded and that often display telangiectasias. They are often friable, and many patients assume that the bleeding, eroded lesions are the result of trauma. Unlike typical scratches and mild trauma, however, BCCs will not spontaneously heal or resolve. In patients with dark skin types, the lesion can be skin-colored rather than pinkish-red. In addition, in patients presenting with pigmented BCC, the lesion can appear brown or blue-brown rather than the typical pinkish-red.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a slow-growing, eroded, or friable papule or nodule with prominent telangiectasia in an area of sun-exposed, sun-damaged skin is basal-cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma is a subtype of squamous-cell carcinoma that grows very rapidly into a large nodule with a central keratin-filled core, resembling a volcano.

D) INCORRECT:

Melanomas tend to have irregular pigmentation with an irregular or asymmetric border. However, amelanotic melanomas can be mistaken for BCCs because they present as pinkish-red macules or papules. If a cutaneous malignancy is suspected, skin biopsy is the best diagnostic test; it is low risk, low cost, and highly sensitive and specific.

E) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell carcinomas tend to grow more rapidly than BCCs and are often erythematous, scaly papules, patches, or plaques. They are less likely than basal-cell carcinomas to have a pearly border or telangiectasias. Differentiating these two types of cancer clinically may be challenging, as there is some degree of clinical overlap and biopsy is indicated regardless.

questions.text:
A 94-year-old woman presents for routine follow-up of chronic medical problems. Her medical history is significant for advanced congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and multiple nonmelanoma skin cancers. She was hospitalized twice in the past year for heart failure exacerbations. She takes numerous medications, including anticoagulation for her atrial fibrillation. She resides in an assisted-living facility and requires partial assistance with activities of daily living. She is cognitively intact and able to participate in medical decision-making.
She appears frail but is not in any distress. She has several small scars from previous skin cancer excisions. In addition, you notice an 12-mm asymptomatic skin lesion on her upper chest (figure). The patient reports that it has been present for several years, with minimal progression. You discuss the possible diagnosis for this lesion, and you offer to biopsy the lesion or refer her to a dermatologist for possible biopsy or treatment. She prefers not to have a skin biopsy or a dermatology referral, because she would like to minimize medical interventions and additional medical appointments. However, she says she will do whatever you recommend.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If treatment for BCC is warranted, the choice of treatment depends on the location and characteristics of the lesion and on patient preferences. For superficial BCC (which appears as a thin, scaly pink patch or plaque), topical imiquimod and fluorouracil cream are the primary options. Observation is a reasonable option in this older patient with limited life expectancy.

B) INCORRECT:

It is appropriate to respect the patient’s stated preference rather than persuade her to undergo biopsy or excision. Treatment is not likely to benefit her within her lifetime; moreover, biopsy and treatment may be associated with adverse effects that are usually minor but may be distressing for this patient (e.g., pain, infection, bleeding, poor wound healing, scarring, or need for assistance with wound care).

C) CORRECT:

A pearly papule with prominent central telangiectasia is the classic presentation of a basal-cell carcinoma (BCC), a typically slow-growing, nonlethal, nonmelanoma skin cancer.

Observation is a reasonable option in this older patient with limited life expectancy. It is appropriate to respect the patient’s stated preference rather than persuade her to undergo biopsy or excision. Treatment is not likely to benefit her within her lifetime; moreover, biopsy and treatment may be associated with adverse effects that are usually minor but may be distressing for this patient (e.g., pain, infection, bleeding, poor wound healing, scarring, or need for assistance with wound care). If the lesion becomes symptomatic or grows more rapidly, biopsy and treatment can be reconsidered.

If treatment for BCC is warranted, the choice of treatment depends on the location and characteristics of the lesion and on patient preferences. For nodular BCC, options include surgical excision, electrodessication and curettage, and Mohs micrographic surgery. For superficial BCC (which appears as a thin, scaly pink patch or plaque), topical imiquimod and fluorouracil cream are the primary options.

Key learning point: A suspected basal-cell carcinoma in an older patient with limited life expectancy can be managed with observation.

D) INCORRECT:

It is appropriate to respect the patient’s stated preference rather than persuade her to undergo biopsy or excision. Treatment is not likely to benefit her within her lifetime; moreover, biopsy and treatment may be associated with adverse effects that are usually minor but may be distressing for this patient (e.g., pain, infection, bleeding, poor wound healing, scarring, or need for assistance with wound care).

E) INCORRECT:

If treatment for BCC is warranted, the choice of treatment depends on the location and characteristics of the lesion and on patient preferences. For superficial BCC (which appears as a thin, scaly pink patch or plaque), topical imiquimod and fluorouracil cream are the primary options. Observation is a reasonable option in this older patient with limited life expectancy.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a skin lesion on her forehead that has grown progressively larger during the past 3 years. The lesion now measures 8 mm (figure) and occasionally bleeds when the patient washes her face. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications.
What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this skin lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment with liquid nitrogen cryotherapy would not be appropriate for this patient without first confirming the diagnosis with a skin biopsy. Cryotherapy is reserved for other types of lesions, such as warts and precancers (actinic keratoses), but not nodular BCC.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s lesion, having been present for 3 years and lacking erythema and warmth, is not consistent with infection. Mupirocin ointment (used for bacterial infection) is not beneficial treatment for BCC.

C) CORRECT:

A pearly papule with prominent telangiectasia that has been persistent for several years is a classic presentation of a nodular basal-cell carcinoma (BCC), a common form of nonmelanoma skin cancer.

BCC lesions commonly manifest with central erosion, prominent telangiectasia (as in this case), or both. The differential diagnosis of the lesion in this case includes:
• Sebaceous hyperplasia, which typically manifests as a yellow to pink-colored umbilicated papule on the face
• A benign nevus, which typically has a skin- or pigmented color and does not have distinguishing features such as a prominent telangiectasia
• Amelanotic melanoma, which may be indistinguishable from a nodular BCC

A skin biopsy is critical to determine the histopathologic identity of this lesion to guide appropriate treatment. A shave biopsy would be a reasonable first step to sample this lesion and confirm a tissue diagnosis before referral for more definitive treatment. Mohs micrographic surgery — a tissue-sparing technique that also confirms the complete removal of skin cancer before surgical closure — is the most appropriate treatment for a nodular BCC of this size on the face.

Key learning point: First-line management of a suspected nodular basal-cell carcinoma on the forehead of a healthy 64-year-old patient is skin biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids (such as clobetasol propionate) are not beneficial treatments for BCC.

E) INCORRECT:

Although imiquimod 5% cream can be used as a treatment for BCC, its use is reserved for the superficial subtype of BCC.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of a skin lesion on his nose. The lesion has gradually increased in size since it first appeared 11 months ago. He is a farmer and lives together with his wife. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 1–2 glasses of whiskey on weekends. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows a nontender lesion at the right medial canthus. An image of the lesion is shown. Molluscum contagiosum manifests as an individual or, more commonly, multiple pearly papules with a central depression. Although it is mostly seen in children, it may also affect adults, especially if they are immunocompromised. Image Description:

Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

While keratoacanthomas may appear as an erythematous nodule with a central crater, which would be consistent with this patient's lesion, they do not have a pearly appearance or a rolled border. An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.

These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

C) CORRECT:

This farmer presents with a slow-growing, nontender, pearly nodule with a rolled border and central ulceration, which is consistent with basal cell carcinoma (BCC). A pearly induration with a rolled border suggests another diagnosis.
Image Description:

A solitary, partially pigmented nodule is visible on this patient's lower lip.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

E) INCORRECT:

While actinic keratosis typically affects patients over the age of 50 and is also associated with sun exposure, it does not manifest as pearly nodules surrounding a central, ulcerative depression. Instead, actinic keratosis presents with dry and scaly patches of skin.
Image Description:

Left temporal and cheek region of a 75-year-old female patient with long-term exposure to UV radiation: All three skin lesions are erythematous. There is an atropic crater in the upper lesion. Yellow-brown, squamous changes can be seen in the lower two lesions. This dermatological findings, in association with the patient's history of long-term UV radiation exposure, most likely indicates actinic keratosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because of a lesion on his eyelid for 6 months. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. He initially dismissed it as a “skin tag” but the lesion has increased in size over the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease. Current medications include sitagliptin, metformin, aspirin, and simvastatin. He retired 3 years ago from his job as a construction contractor. Examination shows a 1-cm (0.4-in) flesh-colored, nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders. There is no lymphadenopathy. A shave biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wide local excision is a surgical procedure in which the tumor and a small margin of normal tissue are removed after the diagnosis has been established. This technique is mainly used for the treatment of melanoma. Although this procedure may also be used to treat BCCs located on the trunk or extremities, the location of this patient's BCC requires a different technique that minimizes the removal of normal tissue.

Wide local excision should not be confused with an excisional biopsy, which is a diagnostic procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cryotherapy can be used for the treatment of superficial BCC, it is not widely accepted as a first-line therapy; recurrence rates are often higher when compared to other therapies. Also, because cryotherapy does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical chemotherapy with imiquimod or 5-fluorouracil is indicated for the treatment of small superficial BCCs. Although topical chemotherapy may be effective in treating some cases of BCC, it is associated with various side effects (redness, edema) and therefore not recommended as a first-line therapy. Additionally, as this technique does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.

D) CORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery, a procedure in which the tumor is removed layer by layer and each layer is examined for tumor cells, is the standard treatment for BCCs that are not located on the trunk or extremities. It is especially advantageous for functionally or cosmetically sensitive tumor locations such as the eyelid because it ensures complete tumor removal while sparing unaffected skin. As BCCs do not metastasize, the prognosis is excellent, but close follow-up (every 6–12 months) is warranted to evaluate for local recurrence and new tumors.
Image Description:

Medial canthus of the left eye

An irregularly circumscribed nodule of approximately 0.5 cm in diameter with a central scaling, retraction, and a pearly, cord-like border is seen. In conjunction with the localization, these symptoms suggest basal cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Laser ablation with a carbon dioxide laser is an alternative treatment for superficial BCCs and is often used when other therapies fail. Although this approach may treat some cases of BCC effectively, other techniques are preferred because of lower recurrence rates. Additionally, as this technique does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.
questions.hint: A nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders on the eyelid in an individual with occupational sun exposure suggests basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with a friable nodule on her chin that she first noticed a year ago and initially attributed to trauma from manual epilation of unwanted facial hair. She thinks that the lesion has gotten larger during the past year. A photograph of the lesion is shown. She has fair skin and moderate actinic damage. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiosarcomas generally manifest as purplish-red vascular plaques or nodules. They typically occur on the breast following radiation or on the head or neck in older patients. They can also occur on the limbs (such as the Stewart-Treves syndrome after axillary lymph-node dissection).

B) CORRECT:

Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common cancer in the United States and the most common type of skin cancer overall. Lesions are typically pearly, translucent papules or nodules that may become centrally eroded and that often display telangiectasias. They are often friable, and many patients assume that the bleeding, eroded lesions are the result of trauma. Unlike typical scratches and mild trauma, however, BCCs will not spontaneously heal or resolve. In patients with dark skin types, the lesion can be skin-colored rather than pinkish-red. In addition, in patients presenting with pigmented BCC, the lesion can appear brown or blue-brown rather than the typical pinkish-red.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a slow-growing, eroded, or friable papule or nodule with prominent telangiectasia in an area of sun-exposed, sun-damaged skin is basal-cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma is a subtype of squamous-cell carcinoma that grows very rapidly into a large nodule with a central keratin-filled core, resembling a volcano.

D) INCORRECT:

Melanomas tend to have irregular pigmentation with an irregular or asymmetric border. However, amelanotic melanomas can be mistaken for BCCs because they present as pinkish-red macules or papules. If a cutaneous malignancy is suspected, skin biopsy is the best diagnostic test; it is low risk, low cost, and highly sensitive and specific.

E) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell carcinomas tend to grow more rapidly than BCCs and are often erythematous, scaly papules, patches, or plaques. They are less likely than basal-cell carcinomas to have a pearly border or telangiectasias. Differentiating these two types of cancer clinically may be challenging, as there is some degree of clinical overlap and biopsy is indicated regardless.
questions.hint: This patient's lesion most commonly occurs on areas of sun-exposed skin.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with a 1.5-cm lesion on his left temple that has gradually increased in size over 8 months. He works outdoors and has had multiple severe sunburns during adolescence. He denies pain or itching. On examination, the lesion has a pearly appearance with rolled, raised borders and visible telangiectasias. The center appears slightly depressed, and there is occasional mild crusting on the surface. The lesion sometimes bleeds with minimal trauma. There is no family history of skin malignancies. No other lesions are noted on full body exam, and vital signs are normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is associated with sun exposure but typically presents as a firm, erythematous, scaly lesion with a rough, hyperkeratotic surface. The lesion described lacks these features and instead has a pearly appearance with rolled borders and telangiectasias, which are not typical of SCC.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignant melanoma often presents with asymmetry, irregular borders, and color variation. The lesion described has a smooth, pearly appearance with rolled borders and telangiectasias, lacking the typical features of melanoma such as heterogeneous pigmentation and irregularity.

C) CORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma typically occurs in older individuals with significant sun exposure, as seen in this patient with a history of outdoor work and sunburns. The lesion's pearly appearance, rolled borders, visible telangiectasias, and central depression are characteristic features. These lesions often bleed with minimal trauma due to their fragile surface. The pathogenesis involves UV-induced DNA damage in basal keratinocytes, leading to dysregulated proliferation. The lesion's slow growth and location on a sun-exposed area further support this diagnosis.

Key learning point: A slowly enlarging lesion that does not heal and bleeds when traumatized is suggestive of basal cell carcinoma, the most common type of skin cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis presents as small, rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed skin. The lesion described is larger, with a pearly appearance, rolled borders, and telangiectasias, which are not consistent with the subtle, scaly nature of actinic keratoses.

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer has a pearly lesion on his left cheek that bleeds easily. Which factor best explains its common predilection for facial skin?

choices.text: Reduced immune surveillance in facial dermis
High density of hair follicles in facial region

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The facial dermis has robust immune surveillance, with a dense network of immune cells. The development of basal cell carcinoma on the face is more related to cumulative UV radiation exposure, which can induce local immunosuppression, rather than an inherent reduction in immune surveillance.

B) INCORRECT:

While facial skin has many hair follicles, their density does not contribute to the development of basal cell carcinoma. The lesion arises from the basal layer of the epidermis, and its facial predilection is due to environmental factors like UV exposure, not follicular density.

C) INCORRECT:

Shaving and minor trauma do not cause the molecular damage leading to basal cell carcinoma. The lesion's development is linked to chronic UV radiation exposure, which causes DNA damage affecting genes involved in cell-cycle regulation, rather than repeated minor injuries.

D) CORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma commonly occurs on facial skin due to chronic ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure, particularly UVB, which causes DNA damage by forming cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers. These dimers can lead to mutations in genes like p53, disrupting cell cycle regulation and apoptosis, thus promoting carcinogenesis. The face is frequently exposed to the sun, especially in outdoor occupations, making UV exposure a key factor in the development of these lesions.

Key learning point: The face is the most common primary location for basal cell carcinoma due to its frequent exposure to ultraviolet radiation from the sun.
Image Description:

A pearly nodule with central atrophy and peripheral telangiectatic vessels is visible on the tip of this patient's nose.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to your clinic because of a lesion on his eyelid that has been present for 6 months. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. He initially thought it was a “skin tag,” but it has increased in size over the past 3 months. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease. His medications are sitagliptin, metformin, aspirin, and simvastatin. He retired 3 years ago from work as a construction contractor. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a 1-cm flesh-colored, nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders on the eyelid. There is no lymphadenopathy. A shave biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery, a procedure in which the tumor is removed layer by layer and each layer is examined for tumor cells, is the standard treatment for BCCs that are not located on the trunk or extremities. It is especially advantageous for functionally or cosmetically sensitive tumor locations such as the eyelid because it ensures complete tumor removal while sparing unaffected skin. As BCCs do not metastasize, the prognosis is excellent, but close follow-up (every 6–12 months) is warranted to evaluate for local recurrence and new tumors.

Key learning point: Mohs micrographic surgery is the preferred treatment for basal cell carcinoma on the eyelid, as it maximizes tumor removal while preserving healthy tissue in cosmetically and functionally sensitive areas.
Image Description:

Medial canthus of the left eye

An irregularly circumscribed nodule of approximately 0.5 cm in diameter with a central scaling, retraction, and a pearly, cord-like border is seen. In conjunction with the localization, these symptoms suggest basal cell carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical chemotherapy with imiquimod or 5-fluorouracil is indicated for the treatment of small superficial BCCs. Although topical chemotherapy may be effective in treating some cases of BCC, it is associated with various side effects (redness, edema) and therefore not recommended as a first-line therapy. Additionally, as this technique does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Wide local excision is a surgical procedure in which the tumor and a small margin of normal tissue are removed after the diagnosis has been established. This technique is mainly used for the treatment of melanoma. Although this procedure may also be used to treat BCCs located on the trunk or extremities, the location of this patient's BCC requires a different technique that minimizes the removal of normal tissue.

Wide local excision should not be confused with an excisional biopsy, which is a diagnostic procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Although cryotherapy can be used for the treatment of superficial BCC, it is not widely accepted as a first-line therapy; recurrence rates are often higher when compared to other therapies. Also, because cryotherapy does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Laser ablation with a carbon dioxide laser is an alternative treatment for superficial BCCs and is often used when other therapies fail. Although this approach may treat some cases of BCC effectively, other techniques are preferred because of lower recurrence rates. Additionally, as this technique does not involve microscopic observation of the tissue, assessing the extent of tumor removal is not possible.
questions.hint: A nodular, nontender lesion with rolled borders on the eyelid in an individual with occupational sun exposure suggests basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a friable papule on her chin that she first noticed a year ago. She initially thought it was due to trauma from manual epilation of unwanted facial hair. She reports that the lesion has increased in size over the past year. She has fair skin and moderate actinic damage. A photograph of the lesion is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma is a subtype of squamous-cell carcinoma that grows very rapidly into a large nodule with a central keratin-filled core, resembling a volcano.

B) INCORRECT:

Melanomas tend to have irregular pigmentation with an irregular or asymmetric border. However, amelanotic melanomas can be mistaken for BCCs because they present as pinkish-red macules or papules. If a cutaneous malignancy is suspected, skin biopsy is the best diagnostic test; it is low risk, low cost, and highly sensitive and specific.

C) INCORRECT:

Angiosarcomas generally manifest as purplish-red vascular plaques or nodules. They typically occur on the breast following radiation or on the head or neck in older patients. They can also occur on the limbs (such as the Stewart-Treves syndrome after axillary lymph-node dissection).

D) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell carcinomas tend to grow more rapidly than BCCs and are often erythematous, scaly papules, patches, or plaques. They are less likely than basal-cell carcinomas to have a pearly border or telangiectasias. Differentiating these two types of cancer clinically may be challenging, as there is some degree of clinical overlap and biopsy is indicated regardless.

E) CORRECT:

Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer overall. Lesions are typically pearly, translucent papules that may become centrally eroded and that often display telangiectasias. They are often friable, and many patients assume that the bleeding, eroded lesions are the result of trauma. Unlike typical scratches and mild trauma, however, BCCs will not spontaneously heal or resolve. In patients with dark skin types, the lesion can be skin-colored rather than pinkish-red. In addition, in patients presenting with pigmented BCC, the lesion can appear brown or blue-brown rather than the typical pinkish-red.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a slow-growing, eroded, or friable papule with prominent telangiectasia in an area of sun-exposed, sun-damaged skin is basal-cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient's lesion most commonly occurs on areas of sun-exposed skin.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. While obtaining his history, he asks you about a facial lesion that has been growing over 4 months. The lesion intermittently bleeds. He has a history of extensive sun exposure and multiple prior skin cancers. Physical examination is as shown. The patient asks if this needs immediate treatment since his previous skin cancers were treated urgently. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electrocautery is inappropriate for suspected malignant lesions and is outside the scope of emergency medicine practice for non-urgent skin lesions. Destructive therapy without tissue diagnosis eliminates the opportunity for histopathologic examination, which is essential for confirming malignancy and determining appropriate definitive treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

The clinical features of a translucent nodule with central depression and visible vasculature in a sun-exposed area are concerning for malignancy rather than infection. Empirical antibiotic therapy would delay proper evaluation and potentially allow disease progression.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The clinical features of a translucent nodule with rolled borders and telangiectasias on sun-exposed skin in an older adult with extensive sun exposure history are highly suggestive of basal cell carcinoma. A skin biopsy is required for diagnostic confirmation and histological subtyping before definitive treatment planning. Emergency physicians should recognize concerning skin lesions and initiate appropriate referrals even when patients present for unrelated complaints.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency physicians typically do not perform elective excisions of suspected skin cancers. Facial lesions require careful consideration of cosmetic outcomes, proper margin assessment, and specialized closure techniques. Additionally, risk stratification determines whether standard excision or Mohs micrographic surgery is indicated, which requires dermatologic expertise and histologic diagnosis first.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergency physicians do not initiate topical cancer therapies. Imiquimod therapy requires confirmed histologic diagnosis of low-risk superficial basal cell carcinoma and ongoing dermatologic monitoring for treatment response and potential adverse effects.

questions.text: A 72-year-old retired farmer presents for evaluation of a skin lesion on his nose that has slowly enlarged over the past year. He reports it occasionally bleeds with minimal trauma and forms a crust that falls off, but the underlying lesion never fully heals.  A photograph of the lesion is shown. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A shave biopsy is the preferred initial diagnostic procedure for a suspected BCC, especially for a raised lesion like this papule. This technique uses a flexible blade to remove a superficial, horizontal slice of tissue, including the epidermis and superficial dermis. It is quick, minimally invasive, and provides an adequate sample for the pathologist to confirm the diagnosis of BCC. Once confirmed, definitive treatment like Mohs micrographic surgery (preferred for high-risk areas like the nose), excision, or electrodesiccation can be planned.

B) INCORRECT:

Expectant management with dermoscopy and digital monitoring would be inappropriate for a lesion with such classic features of skin cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy removes the entire lesion with a margin of normal skin and is both diagnostic and therapeutic. However, for a suspected basal cell carcinoma in a cosmetically sensitive area like the nose, a full excision is typically reserved for treatment after a diagnosis is confirmed.

D) INCORRECT:

Curettage and electrodesiccation is a reasonable treatment for some patients with BCC. It involves scraping away the cancerous tissue and then using electricity to cauterize the base. Because this method destroys the tissue architecture, it does not yield a specimen suitable for detailed histopathologic analysis, particularly margin assessment. A different diagnostic step is first indicated to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: The patient's pearly nodule with telangiectasias and central ulceration on a sun-exposed area is highly suspicious of nodular basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents for evaluation of a non-healing lesion on his nose. He states it appeared about 9 months ago and has slowly enlarged. It occasionally bleeds with minor trauma, such as toweling his face. He worked as a construction worker for 30 years. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nodular melanoma can present as a firm, growing papule or nodule that may ulcerate and bleed. However, the slow, 9-month growth is less typical, as nodular melanomas often grow rapidly. Furthermore, the hallmark features of a pearly border and fine overlying telangiectasias are characteristic of a different diagnosis, not melanoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma is also common on sun-exposed skin and can present as a non-healing, ulcerated lesion that bleeds. However, it typically appears as an indurated, erythematous papule or plaque with a scaly or crusted surface. The pearly appearance and fine telangiectasias seen here are not characteristic features of squamous cell carcinoma.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for nodular basal cell carcinoma (BCC), the most common subtype of BBC. Key features include the location on a sun-exposed area (nose), a history of chronic sun exposure (construction worker), and slow growth. The physical examination findings of a nodule with a pearly appearance, a rolled border, and overlying telangiectasias are characteristic. The history of a lesion that bleeds easily with minor trauma and fails to heal is also highly suggestive. BCC arises from the basal cells of the epidermis and is locally invasive but has a very low potential for metastasis. It is the most common form of skin cancer in the United States.

D) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous hyperplasia is a benign condition that presents as yellowish or flesh-colored papules on the face. While these lesions can have telangiectasias, they classically have central umbilication corresponding to a sebaceous duct opening. They do not typically have a raised, pearly border and would not be expected to repeatedly bleed.

E) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a common pre-malignant lesion found on sun-damaged skin. However, it typically presents as a dry, rough, scaly, or sandpaper-like macule or papule on an erythematous base. It does not form a firm nodule with a pearly, rolled border, ulceration, or telangiectasias.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents for a non-healing lesion on his upper back that has been present for 9 months. It has slowly grown and sometimes bleeds with minor trauma. His medical history is significant for extensive sun exposure from his career in landscaping. On examination, there is an 8-mm translucent papule with a slightly raised border and fine telangiectasias on the surface. A shave biopsy confirms a nodular basal cell carcinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for this lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod is an immune response modifier that can be used for some skin cancers. However, its primary indication is for superficial BCC when resection or radiotherapy is not feasible, not the nodular subtype, which has a deeper component.

B) CORRECT:

For low-risk primary basal cell carcinoma, standard surgical excision is the first-line treatment, offering high cure rates (over 95%). The standard recommendation is to excise the lesion with 4-mm clinical margins to ensure complete removal of cancerous cells. This method allows for histopathologic confirmation that the margins are clear of tumor, which is a key advantage over destructive techniques. Following excision, the tissue is sent for pathology to verify that the entire tumor has been removed.

C) INCORRECT:

Mohs surgery is a specialized technique with very high cure rates that involves real-time, intraoperative margin assessment. It is primarily indicated for high-risk BCCs or for the management of positive margins after surgical excision. For a low-risk nodular BCC on the trunk, Mohs surgery is generally not necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a treatment option for BCC but is typically reserved for patients who are poor surgical candidates or for large tumors where surgical excision would result in significant morbidity. For a healthy patient with a low-risk primary BCC, a different management approach is preferred due to its high efficacy and avoidance of long-term radiation-related side effects like scarring and hypopigmentation.
questions.hint: Nodular basal cell carcinoma is the most frequently occurring subtype of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) and is categorized as a low-risk subtype.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of working as a farmer presents for evaluation of a lesion on his right lower eyelid. He states it began as a small 'pimple' about 9 months ago and has slowly enlarged. It occasionally bleeds with minimal trauma. On physical examination, there is a 5-mm firm, pearly papule with rolled borders and overlying telangiectasias located 3 mm from the medial canthus. A shave biopsy performed last week confirmed a diagnosis of nodular basal cell carcinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod is a topical immunomodulator approved for the treatment of superficial basal cell carcinoma in low-risk locations. This patient has a nodular subtype, for which topical therapies are less effective. Additionally, using topical treatments on or near the eyelid carries a risk of ocular irritation and is not recommended for high-risk locations where margin control is essential.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is a destructive modality that can be used for small, low-risk basal cell carcinomas. Like electrodessication and curettage, it does not provide histologic confirmation of tumor removal and is associated with higher recurrence rates, especially in high-risk areas. Its use on the eyelid is contraindicated due to the risk of incomplete treatment and potential for significant scarring and pigmentary changes.

C) CORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery is the treatment of choice for basal cell carcinomas located in high-risk areas, such as the face, eyelids, nose, ears, and genitals (the "H-zone"). This technique involves sequential excision of tissue layers with immediate microscopic examination of 100% of the surgical margins until the tumor is completely removed. This approach ensures the highest cure rates (over 99% for primary BCCs) while maximally sparing healthy tissue. For a lesion on the eyelid near the medial canthus, tissue conservation is critical to preserve function (e.g., prevent ectropion, epiphora) and achieve the best cosmetic outcome.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard surgical excision with 4-mm margins is an effective treatment for low-risk, well-defined basal cell carcinomas in non-critical locations, such as the trunk or extremities. However, for a high-risk location like the eyelid, this approach may unnecessarily remove healthy tissue, leading to functional and cosmetic deficits. Furthermore, it has a lower cure rate in this area compared to techniques with complete margin assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Electrodessication and curettage is a destructive technique often used for small, superficial, or nodular basal cell carcinomas in low-risk locations. This method does not allow for histologic confirmation of tumor clearance, leading to higher recurrence rates. It is contraindicated for tumors on the eyelid due to the risk of incomplete removal and significant scarring in a functionally important area.
questions.hint: The choice of surgical intervention for basal cell carcinoma is heavily influenced by the lesion's anatomic location.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a lesion on his nose. The lesion appeared 1 year ago and has slowly increased in size since then. There is no associated pain or pruritus. He is otherwise healthy and has played golf every other day since his retirement. He says that he used to use tanning beds regularly in the past because he “liked the tanned look.” A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is the second most common type of skin cancer. It can occur on the face, is slow-growing, painless, and occasionally ulcerates, as seen here. In addition, advanced age and chronic exposure to UV light are risk factors for cSCC. However, cSCC of the face typically involves the cheeks and lower lip rather than the nose, and the ulcerated form of cSCC typically has everted edges rather than the rolled edges seen in this photograph.
Image Description:

A solitary ulcer, approx. 2 cm in diameter, is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

B) INCORRECT:

A cherry hemangioma is a vascular skin tumor that typically manifests in middle-aged and older adults. However, a cherry hemangioma appears as a red, dome-shaped papule, not an ulcer, and is typically located on the trunk or upper extremities rather than the face.
Image Description:

Photograph of the skin (unknown location)

Two small erythematous papules with a reddish-purple appearance are visible in the center of the image.

C) CORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC), which is the most common type of malignant skin tumor, typically manifests as a slow-growing, nonhealing ulcer with a central depression and rolled borders (rodent ulcer), a pearly white nodule with superficial telangiectasis, or a scaling plaque (superficial BCC). This patient's history of using tanning beds and playing golf regularly increases his UV exposure, which is a risk factor for developing BCC. Facial BCC typically occurs above the line joining the earlobe and the corner of the mouth (e.g., on the forehead, eyelids, nose, nasolabial fold, upper lip). BCC is locally invasive but rarely metastasizes.

D) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma, which is a type of skin cancer, occurs more commonly in older individuals and typically arises on skin damaged by UV light. However, keratoacanthoma manifests as a round, erythematous nodule with a central keratin-containing plug. Moreover, keratoacanthomas grow rapidly, within 2–3 months, unlike the slow-growing lesion in this patient.
Image Description:

Upper body of an older female patient

A 1x1-cm round, erythematous nodule with a central crater is visible on the anterior chest wall. Keratoacanthomas arise from hair follicles or squamous cells of the skin. The main feature differentiating a keratoacanthoma from a squamous cell carcinoma is its rapid growth (keratoacanthomas tend to develop within a few weeks).

E) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is a type of benign skin tumor commonly seen in older individuals. It can arise on the face but appears as a greasy, wax-like, darkly pigmented macule or warty papule, not an ulcer.
Image Description:

Photograph of the face of an adult patient

Two large, brown, fissured papules with a characteristic stuck-on appearance can be seen.

F) INCORRECT:

Nodular melanoma (NM) is a type of malignant melanoma, which often arises on skin damaged by UV light and is more common in older individuals. However, NM usually grows rapidly over weeks, unlike the slow-growing lesion in this patient, and manifests as a dark-pigmented or red (amelanotic NM) nodule that can occasionally ulcerate at the surface; the base of this patient's ulcer is flush against the skin, indicating a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Upper back

A nodular lesion (diameter approx. 4 cm) with central ulceration is visible. The border appears reddened and markedly raised.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nodular melanoma.

G) INCORRECT:

Trichoepithelioma is a tumor of the hair follicle that is commonly located on the cheeks and nose, like this patient's lesion. However, trichoepithelioma typically affects young individuals and appears as a skin-colored papule, unlike the ulcer seen in this older patient.
Image Description:

A sharply demarcated, erythematous and symmetric nodule is visible on the right side of the cheek in the nasolabial fold, right next to the ala nasi. Its diameter is approximately 1cm and it is elevated about 5mm above the surface of the cheek. The lesion is centrally ulcerated.

This appearance is characteristic of trichoepithelioma.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an ulcer with rolled borders and a central depression. A biopsy of the lesion would most likely show palisading nuclei.
